<form onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); checkAnswer('module7_mcq_q94')" data-correct-answer="B">
<strong style="display: block;">According to Modigliani and Miller's propositions in a world without taxes, which statement about the firm's cost of capital is correct?</strong>

<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q94" value="A"> A. The weighted average cost of capital (WACC) increases as leverage increases.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q94" value="B"> B. The firm's WACC remains constant regardless of its capital structure.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q94" value="C"> C. The firm's equity cost remains unchanged as leverage increases.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q94" value="D"> D. The firm's unlevered cost of capital decreases with leverage.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q94" value="E"> E. The firm's value decreases as leverage increases.</label><br>
</form>

<div id="feedback-module7_mcq_q94" class="feedback" data-status="" style="display:none;">
✅ Correct: B. In a no-tax world, Modigliani and Miller’s Proposition I states that the firm's total value and WACC are independent of its capital structure. Leverage only reallocates risk between debt and equity but does not affect the overall cost of capital.
</div>
